title: How to Hem Clothing by Hand

steps.headline: Fit the article first.
steps.description: It is essential to have the person try on the article of clothing for a fitting to allow you to pin it to the correct length.

steps.headline: Place ball or flat-headed stick-pins around the hem.
steps.description: Place them about 3 inches (7.5 cm) apart all the way around the material. Turn it inward as you put in the pins.

steps.headline: Remove the article of clothing.
steps.description: Take the item off carefully to avoid scraping pins on your model.

steps.headline: Thread a needle with thread.
steps.description: Make sure that the thread matches the color of the material as closely as possible.

steps.headline: Double and knot the thread.
steps.description: This provides the strength needed for a hem; the hem takes a lot of punishment from daily wear. (To double the thread, put it through the needle and bring both ends together, tie them in a knot.)

steps.headline: Turn the article of clothing inside out.
steps.description: If the clothing is extremely long, measure and cut some of the excess material off, but leave about 2 inches (5 cm). Finish the raw edge of the fabric so that it does not fray. If you want to let the material out later, simply fold it over a few times, making an edge about two or three inches thick.

steps.headline: Sew around the pinned material.
steps.description: Take up as little fabric as possible with the needle on each stitch. Try to place stitches about 1/2 inch (1.5 cm) apart. You can sew by hand or with a sewing machine, depending on which way suits you most.
